entry.title: Adding New BIP Editors
entry.summary:
The conversation among Ava Chow, Steve Lee, and Tim Ruffing, taking place on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List, delves into the process and requirements for triaging Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs), specifically highlighting the roles and permissions involved in modifying existing BIPs and managing newly proposed BIPs. The discussion illuminates that for amendments to current BIPs, the authors are readily identifiable via the header information of each proposal, allowing anyone with access to this information to contact the relevant GitHub accounts directly for approval of changes. This implies that initiating changes or updates doesn't necessitate special permissions if at least one author consents to the modifications, subsequently informing the editors.
Furthermore, the dialogue touches upon the handling of newly proposed BIPs, suggesting that individuals possessing a thorough understanding of the BIP process could contribute significantly without needing explicit permissions. This is particularly true for identifying straightforward issues, such as missing sections, where they can provide valuable feedback by referencing specific examples ([GitHub pull request review](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1500pullrequestreview-1796550166)).
Despite the open nature of contributing to the BIP process, both through direct amendments and feedback on new proposals, there's a consensus on the necessity for an additional BIP editor. This need stems from the existing backlog in assigning numbers to new BIPs and merging approved changes into existing documents, indicating a bottleneck in the process flow. The discussion suggests that the proposed candidates for the editor role are well-suited to address these challenges, implying a move towards enhancing the efficiency of the BIP management process.
